title: Scot J Matkovich
text:
Welcome!
I hold a Ph.D in biochemistry and molecular biology and currently work as a biological research scientist in drug discovery for cardiovascular and metabolic diseases. One of my greatest interests outside my scientific career and the improvement of public health is making music on the piano in the Western classical tradition; a gateway to many other musical pursuits.

Professional experience
My LinkedIn page has a comprehensive profile. As a summary:

Director / Principal Research Scientist | Eli Lilly and Co | 2018 - present
Assistant Professor, Department of Medicine | Washington University in St Louis | 2011-2018
Senior Scientist, Department of Medicine (PI: Gerald W Dorn II) | Washington University in St Louis | 2008-2011
Postdoctoral appointments at Columbia University in New York (PI: Andrew R Marks) and the University of Cincinnati (PI: Gerald W Dorn II)


Education
Formal degrees

Ph.D (Biochemistry & Molecular Biology), University of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia, 2000. Thesis title ‘Inositol phosphate generation in the heart: mechanisms and functional relevance’. Advisor: Elizabeth A Woodcock
BSc (Hons.), Department of Physiology, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia, 1996.
BA / BSc, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Australia, 1995. Majors: French, German, music, biochemistry, physiology

Certifications

Multiple edX and Coursera programs in statistics and data science, including most elements of the reputable Johns Hopkins Data Science Specialization series, 2017-2022
A.Mus.A (Associate in Music, Australia) in piano performance from the Australian Music Examinations Board, 1989

title: About this website
text:
This site was built by Scot Matkovich using Quarto and is hosted on GitHub Pages.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites

title: First post
text:
A start to documenting my exploration of ‘biological data science’
This is merely a first post to establish a personal blog, which also serves as a brief set of acknowledgments and future resources. Any stated opinions or recommendations are entirely my own, independent of professional affiliation.
Resources which were invaluable in getting this website and blog started were:

The description of the Quarto system in Hadley Wickham’s 2nd edition of R for data science
Excellent walk-through tutorials on establishing a website and blog with the Quarto system from Samantha Csik
Some of the official Quarto documentation

For future enhancement and exploration, I’m looking forward to exploring:

The resources listed at the ‘Awesome Quarto’ github repository
More of Samantha Csik’s tutorials, specifically on SASS/CSS website customization
